title: 110_hr476
content: Loss of pensions accrued during service as a member of Congress for abusing the public trust. Loss of pensions accrued during service as a member of Congress for abusing the public trust. An amendment to the Civil Service Retirement System states that individuals finally convicted of specific offenses will not have their service counted for retirement purposes, except for service rendered as a Member. Offenses include acts or omissions needed to satisfy certain elements. The individual will be entitled to their lump-sum credit attributable to the excluded service. The amendment to the Civil Service Retirement System specifies that individuals convicted of certain offenses will lose their pensions accrued during their time as a Member of Congress. The offenses must directly relate to the individual's official duties and be committed after the enactment of the subsection. The specified offenses include bribery of public officials, acting as agents of foreign principals, and conspiracy to commit offenses or defraud the United States under title 18. The amendment to the Civil Service Retirement System states that individuals convicted of certain offenses, including bribery of public officials and acting as agents of foreign principals, will lose their pensions accrued during their time as a Member of Congress. This includes conspiracy to commit offenses or defraud the United States under title 18, such as perjury and subornation of perjury. Individuals convicted of specified offenses will lose their retirement system eligibility as a Member of Congress. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for this, including interest limitations on lump-sum payments and provisions for payments to spouses or children of affected individuals. The amendment to Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, allows for adjustments in payments to Members of Congress convicted of specified offenses, ensuring that nonpayable amounts are considered necessary in certain circumstances. The term 'Member' and 'child' are defined as per specific sections of the code. The amendment to Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, excludes the service of an individual finally convicted of specific offenses from being considered for certain purposes. This applies to service rendered as a Member, and the individual is entitled to be paid their lump-sum credit attributable to such service. The offenses must occur while the individual is a Member to qualify. The amendment to Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code, excludes individuals convicted of specific offenses from participating in the retirement system while serving as a Member. The offense must directly relate to the individual's official duties, occur after the enactment of the subsection, and result in ineligibility for retirement benefits. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for implementation, including limitations on interest for lump-sum payments. The Office of Personnel Management may provide for payment adjustments to spouses or children of individuals ineligible for retirement benefits due to specific offenses. Lump-sum payments may also be adjusted accordingly. The term 'Member' and 'child' are defined as per specific sections, regardless of other definitions. The House of Representatives passed the bill on January 23, 2007. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
